name: vanadium-titanomagnetite mine operation and beneficiation | iron ore concentrate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24890/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of high-grade titanium slag (94% TiO2) from vanadium-titanomagnetite ore in the city of Panzhihua & Xichang region in China. It includes the activities of ore mining & dressing (during which titanium concentrate is produced) and titanium slag smelting (during which high-grade titanium slag with 94% TiO2 content is produced). The dataset is based on the Gao et al (2018) publication.;For this dataset, the data for mining were taken from Table 1 and figure 2 of the abovementioned source. The waste rock reported in table 1 is not taken into account, because it is assumed that is left on-site and used as backfill material, therefore remaining within system boundaries. Data for infrastructure, land occupation & transformation as well as emissions during mining were approximated with data from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. The data for mining in table 2, column ''ore mining and dressing'' from the Gao et al (2018) publication were not considered due to mass allocation in that specific column. Nevertheless, for the titanium slag smelting process the data were taken from the respective column in table 2 of the Gao et al (2018) publication. Finally, the grade of slag is not reported in the Gao et al (2018) and was instead taken from the Liao et al (2012) publication, since it refers to production of high-grade slag (as intermediate product) in Panzhihua city. The transport distance was also taken from the Liao et al (2012) publication.;;Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.;;Reference 2: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4.

The activity starts with the mining of vanadium-titanomagnetite ore.

The activity ends with the production of high-grade titania slag (94% TiO2). It is assumed that waste rock is left on-site and used as backfill material. For that reason, waste rock is not included in the present dataset.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset assumed valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Natural rutile resources are scarce in China. For that reason, the production of titanium stems from high-grade titanium slag, the production of which includes 2 processes: i) ore mining & dressing process and ii) titanium slag smelting process. During the ore mining and dressing process, ilmenite concentrate (47.82% TiO2) is produced through high-intensity magnetic separation of the middling ore, which is previously produced as a byproduct during the magnetic separation sub-process of the vanadium titano-magnetite ore. During the titanium slag smelting process, the produced ilmenite concentrate from the ore mining & dressing process is mixed with petroleum coke as the reducing agent and pitch as the bonding agent. Afterwards it enters the electric arc furnace, where it is smelted, separating iron from the ilmenite concentrate and obtaining high-grade titanium slag.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is an aggregation of the ore mining and dressing process and the titanium slag smelting process as described in Gao et al (2018). According to the authors of the publication used as a source for this dataset, data for the average vanadium-titanomagnetite ore  were collected through on-site surveys of several representative mining companies in Chinaâ€™s Panzhihua and Xichang region. 

The data are assumed to represent the average production of high-grade titanium slag in China. The majority of the data is based on the work of Gao et al (2018). For this dataset, the inputs/outputs for the ore mining & dressing process were based on Table 1 and figure 2 of the abovementioned source. The waste rock reported in table 1 is not taken into account, because it is assumed that is left on-site and used as backfill material, therefore remaining within system boundaries. The data for mining in table 2, column ''ore mining and dressing'' from the Gao et al (2018) publication were not considered due to mass allocation in that specific column. Nevertheless, for the titanium slag smelting process the data were taken from the respective column in table 2 of the Gao et al (2018) publication, since there is no indication of mass allocation in that column. 

Data for infrastructure, land occupation & transformation as well as emissions during mining were approximated with data from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. Finally, the grade of slag is not reported in the Gao et al and was instead taken from the Liao et al (2012) publication, since it refers to production of high-grade slag (as intermediate product) in Panzhihua city. 
The fuels (raw coal, natural gas, crude oil, diesel and gasoline) have been linked with the respective Ecoinvent heat production datasets (check individual exchange comments). Calculation of the thermal energy is also available in the respective comments. The individual emissions listed in table 2  (CO2, SO2, NOx, CO, CH4, N2O, NMVOC, As, Cd, Cr, Hg, Ni, Pb, V, Zn and Particulates) are not considered here because they represent indirect emissions from the combustion of the abovementioned fuels and electricity production that are already included in the respective Ecoinvent exchanges. Therefore, those emissions are not included in order to avoid double counting. However, the direct carbon monoxide emissions are included here based on the stoichiometric equations of the titanium slag smelting process  (more information on exchange comment section of each emission), as these are direct process emissions (stoichiometric equation: FeTiO3 + C -> Fe + TiO2 + CO).

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

Reference 2: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4.

exchanges.description:
Gao et al (2018) reports in figure 2 reports i) 7.45 tons of iron concentrate produced as a byproduct during the magnetic separation sub-process with a content of 54.96% Fe and ii) 0.63 tons of iron concentrate produced as a byproduct during the high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation sub-process with a content of 51.22% Fe per 1 ton of produced titanium concentrate. The abovementioned sub-processes are part of the ore mining and dressing process. This value was multiplied by 2,2, since approximately 2,2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) (consult titanium in ground exchange comment) . 

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

flow.name: iron ore concentrate
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/071:Mining of iron ores/0710:Mining of iron ores

exchanges.description:
Due to the fact that the infrastructure is not reported in table 2 of Gao et al (2018) publication and has to be included for compliance with the Ecoivent quality guidelines, the value for mine recultivation (8.292E-05 m2) is taken from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. Due to the structure of the dataset, the abovementioned value in that dataset is multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. This scaling factor equals the ratio of titanium extracted from the ground in order to produce 1 kg of titanium slag with 94% TiO2 (2.29 kg - see titanium, in ground exchange comment) to the amount of titanium extracted from the ground based on the abovementioned dataset (0.56824 kg). Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03. 


Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The original amount of electricity required in the ore mining and dressing (after aggregation of the ore mining, magnetic separation and high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation process and adjustment of all inputs presented in Table 1 listed in the following publication to refer to the production of 1 kg of titanium concentrate) & titanium slag smelting process are 846 kWh per ton of concentrate and 4700 kWh per ton of titanium sponge respectively. The second value was taken from Table2, column ''titanium slag smelting'' of the same following publication: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. 
The first value was multiplied by 2.2, since approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) (consult titanium in ground exchange comment). The second value was calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.44787 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset). These two adjusted values were summed in order to obtain the amount of electricity required during the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) for both processes.

Note: The value of electricity reported in table 1 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. This is why the electricity amount reported in Table 1 (after aggregation of the 3 subprocesses of mining and dressing) was instead considered here.

Due to the structure of the dataset, the abovementioned value in that dataset is multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03. 


Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The original amount of graphite electrode (approximated here as battery-grade graphite) required in the titanium slag smelting process is 66.9 kg and represents the amount required for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. This value was adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) (by dividing by 1000 and then by diving again by 1.77473 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti Sponge, 1.77473 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) are needed.
Note: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.4478723 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

exchanges.description:
Due to the fact that the emissions reported in table 2 of Gao et al (2018) publication are aggregated (i.e emissions from electricity production and fuel burning) the emissions from mining are taken from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. Due to the structure of the dataset, the emissions provided in that dataset are multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. This scaling factor equals the ratio of titanium extracted from the ground in order to produce 1 kg of titanium slag with 94% TiO2 (2.29 kg - see titanium, in ground exchange comment) to the amount of titanium extracted from the ground based on the abovementioned dataset (0.56824 kg). Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03.The PM>10 emission amount from the abovementioned dataset is 2,4142E-04 kg.


Reference : Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
The titanium extracted from the ground is based on the following facts: i) The original amount of ore extracted from the ground is 48.88 kg per kg of slag ii) the TiO2 content in the ore is 7.82% (Source: Figure 2 of the following publication) and iii) The % of titanium in TiO2 is 59.93% (Source: https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm). 

Note: The original amount of extracted vanadium titano-magnetite ore during the ore mining and dressing process is 22.15 tons and represents the amount required for the production of 1 ton of titanium concentrate (ilmenite). This value was calculated based on the aggregation of the ore mining, magnetic separation and high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation process and adjustment of all inputs presented in table 1 of the Gao et al (2018) publication to refer to the production of 1 kg of titanium concentrate. 

The amount of ilmenite (FeTiO3) required for the production of 1 kg of titanium slag (94% TiO2) is based on the following facts: i) the ilmenite concentrate has a grade of 47.62% TiO2, according to figure 2 of the abovementioned source ii) the produced high-grade titanium slag has a grade of 94% TiO2 (based on data from Liao et al (2012) from Panzhihua city - data taken from that source because Gao et al 2018 does not mention the grade of high-grade titanium slag produced) and iii) due to absence of data regarding the recovery of titanium during that process, the recovery rate from leaching process is assumed here as the best available approximation, which is 89.45% according to Li et al (2021).

After adjusting for the ore grade, approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2). This means that approximately 48.88 kg of vanadium titano-magnetite ore is required in the end for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2).

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. 

Reference 2: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4.

Reference 3: Li, Y., Chen, S., & Duan, H. (2021). A New Process of Extracting Titanium from Vanadium-Titanium Magnetite. Crystals, 11(4), 327.

flow.name: Titanium
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description:
Gangue is calculated by subtracting the amount of titanium extracted from the ground and the amount of iron extracted from ground from the amount of vanadium titano-magnetite ore extracted from ground (48.88 kg).
Note:The original amount of extracted vanadium titano-magnetite ore during the ore mining and dressing process is 22.15 tons and represents the amount required for the production of 1 ton of titanium concentrate (ilmenite). This value was calculated based on the aggregation of the ore mining, magnetic separation and high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation process and adjustment of all inputs presented in table 1 of the Gao et al (2018) publication to refer to the production of 1 kg of titanium concentrate. 

The amount of ilmenite (FeTiO3) required for the production of 1 kg of titanium slag (94% TiO2) is based on the following facts: i) the ilmenite concentrate has a grade of 47.62% TiO2, according to figure 1 of the abovementioned source ii) the produced high-grade titanium slag has a grade of 94% TiO2 (based on data from Liao et al (2012) from Panzhihua city - data taken from that source because Gao et al 2018 does not mention the grade of high-grade titanium slag produced) and iii) due to absence of data regarding the recovery of titanium during that process, the recovery rate from leaching process is assumed here as the best available approximation, which is 89.45% according to Li et al (2021).

After adjusting for the ore grade, approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2). This means that approximately 48.88 kg of vanadium titano-magnetite ore is required in the end for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2).

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. 

Reference 2: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4.

Reference 3: Li, Y., Chen, S., & Duan, H. (2021). A New Process of Extracting Titanium from Vanadium-Titanium Magnetite. Crystals, 11(4), 327.

flow.name: Gangue
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description:
Gao et al (2018) reports in Table 2 41.6 kg of other residue (approximated here as inert waste) produced as a byproduct during the titanium slag smelting process per kg of produced titanium sponge. This value was divided by 1.77473, since approximately 1.77473 kg of titanium slag 94% TiO2 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge. 

Note: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.44787 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description: Only the direct carbon monoxide emissions are included here. The amount of CO is based on carbon balance. More specifically, the amount of carbon contained in petroleum coke and pitch should equal the amount of carbon present in the carbon monoxide that is emitted. Reason for this approach is that petroleum coke and pitch are essential inputs for the smelting of titania slag and carbon monoxide the essential carbon-based output, during that process.

flow.name: Carbon monoxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Gao et al (2018) reports in figure 2 a total of 13.04 kg of tailings (approximated here as non-sulfidic tailings) produced as a byproduct during the ore mining and dressing process per kg of titanium concentrate (ilmenite). At first, this value was multiplied by 2,2, since approximately 2,2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) (consult titanium in ground exchange comment). Furthermore, it is assumed that the mass of the tailings reported in the Gao et al (2018) publication represents the dry mass of the tailings. This means that the amount of the tailings will be divided by 0.7 (due to the fact that 70% of the tailings' mass is  dry mass in the corresponding treatment dataset).

Note 1: The value of tailings reported in table 2 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. This is why the amount of tailings in figure 2 were considered.

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The original amount of flotation agent (approximated here as an organic chemical) required in the ore mining and dressing is 34.4 kg and represents the amount required for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. These values were taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. The value was adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) (by dividing by 1000 and then by diving again by 1.77473 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti Sponge, 1.77473 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) are needed -  more information on the titanium slag exchange comment). 

Note 1: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.44787 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

Note 2: Exchanges reported in table 1 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication were not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. However, due to lack of data, the amount reported in the Gao et al (2018) publication in that specific column is considered as the best available source of information. 


Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China.

Due to the structure of the dataset, the emissions provided in that dataset are multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. This scaling factor equals the ratio of titanium extracted from the ground in order to produce 1 kg of titanium slag with 94% TiO2 (2.29 kg - see titanium, in ground exchange comment) to the amount of titanium extracted from the ground based on the abovementioned dataset (0.56824 kg). Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03.The PM<2.5 emission amount from the abovementioned dataset is 1.7742E-05 kg.


Reference : Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The original amount of crude oil required in the titanium slag smelting process is 569 kg per ton of titanium sponge respectively. The abovementioned value was taken from Table2, column ''titanium slag smelting'' of the following publication: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. 

The value was adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (by dividing by 1000 to represent the per kg of Ti sponge requirement of crude oil and then by diving by 1.77473, based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti Sponge, 1.77473 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) are needed). Finally, the energy from crude oil is calculated by multiplying the previously calculated amount of crude oil with gross calorific value of crude oil (45.8 MJ/kg according to Table 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3).

Note 1: The value of diesel reported in table 2 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. 
Note 2: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.44787 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

exchanges.description:
It is assumed that 15% of the water used for the production of the slag, is emitted to air, while the rest lands in wastewater. The assumption of is taken from the dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of Ecoinvent. This assumption is considered acceptable, as the Ecoinvent dataset corresponds to the one provided in the Gao et al (2018) publication. However, this exchange was not present in the Gao et al (2018) publication, on which this dataset is based and has been assumed for water balance purposes.


Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
Due to the fact that the land occupation is not reported in table 2 of Gao et al (2018) publication and has to be included for completeness purposes, the value for land occupation (0.0024876 m2*year) is taken from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. Due to the structure of the dataset, the abovementioned value in that dataset is multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. This scaling factor equals the ratio of titanium extracted from the ground in order to produce 1 kg of titanium slag with 94% TiO2 (2.29 kg - see titanium, in ground exchange comment) to the amount of titanium extracted from the ground based on the abovementioned dataset (0.56824 kg). Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03. 

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
Due to the fact that the emissions reported in table 2 of Gao et al (2018) publication are aggregated (i.e emissions from electricity production and fuel burning) the emissions from mining are taken from the Ecoinvent dataset ''ilmenite - magnetite mine operation, GLO'' available in version 3.7.1 of the Ecoinvent database. Due to the structure of the dataset, the emissions provided in that dataset are multiplied by a scaling factor, which is based on the titanium that is extracted from the ground. This scaling factor equals the ratio of titanium extracted from the ground in order to produce 1 kg of titanium slag with 94% TiO2 (2.29 kg - see titanium, in ground exchange comment) to the amount of titanium extracted from the ground based on the abovementioned dataset (0.56824 kg). Therefore, the scaling factor is equal to 4.03.The PM>2,5 and < 10 emission amount from the abovementioned dataset is 9.568E-05 kg. 


Reference : Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The original amount of pitch required in the titanium slag smelting process is 279 kg and represents the amount required for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was taken from Table 2, column ''titanium slag smelting'' of the following publication: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. This value was adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) (by dividing by 1000 and then by diving again by 1.77474 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti Sponge, 1.77474 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2), are needed -  more information on the titanium slag exchange comment). 
Note: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.4478723 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

exchanges.description:
The original amount of gasoline (approximated here as petrol) required during the ore mining and dressing (after aggregation of the ore mining, magnetic separation and high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation process and adjustment of all inputs presented in Table 1 of the Gao et al (2018) to refer to the production of 1 kg of titanium concentrate) is approximately 4.615E-06 kg. 

The abovementioned value was first adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (by multiplying by 2.2 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2), 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate are needed (consult titanium in ground exchange comment for more information). The energy from gasoline is calculated by multiplying the previously calculated amount of gasoline with gross calorific value of gasoline (45.1 MJ/kg according to Table 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3).

Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The iron extracted from the ground is based on the following facts: i) The original amount of ore extracted from the ground is 48.88 kg per kg of slag ii) the Fe content in the ore is 26.44% (Source: Figure 2 of the following publication). 
Note: The original amount of extracted vanadium titano-magnetite ore during the ore mining and dressing process is 22.15 tons and represents the amount required for the production of 1 ton of titanium concentrate (ilmenite). This value was calculated based on the aggregation of the ore mining, magnetic separation and high-intensity magnetic separation and flotation process and adjustment of all inputs presented in table 1 of the Gao et al (2018) publication to refer to the production of 1 kg of titanium concentrate. 

The amount of ilmenite (FeTiO3) required for the production of 1 kg of titanium slag (94% TiO2) is based on the following facts: i) the ilmenite concentrate has a grade of 47.62% TiO2, according to figure 1 of the abovementioned source ii) the produced high-grade titanium slag has a grade of 94% TiO2 (based on data from Liao et al (2012) from Panzhihua city - data taken from that source because Gao et al 2018 does not mention the grade of high-grade titanium slag produced) and iii) due to absence of data regarding the recovery of titanium during that process, the recovery rate from leaching process is assumed here as the best available approximation, which is 89.45% according to Li et al (2021).

After adjusting for the ore grade, approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2). This means that approximately 48.88 kg of vanadium titano-magnetite ore is required in the end for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2).

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240. 

Reference 2: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4.

Reference 3: Li, Y., Chen, S., & Duan, H. (2021). A New Process of Extracting Titanium from Vanadium-Titanium Magnetite. Crystals, 11(4), 327.

flow.name: Iron
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of heat produced from the combustion of natural gas. Gao et al (2018) reports in Table 1 0.177 m3 of natural gas consumption per ton of produced titanium concentrate during the ore mining and dressing process and 29.9 kg per ton of produced titanium sponge during the titanium slag smelting process. Both values were first adjusted to represent the production per kg of Ti concentrate and sponge respectively (division by 1000). 

After this adjustment, the first value was first multiplied by 2.2, since approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) (consult titanium in ground exchange comment) and then multiplied again by 40.3, since the gross calorific value of natural gas is 40.3 MJ/m3. The second value was first divided by 1.77473, based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti Sponge, 1.77473 kg of Ti slag (94% TiO2) are needed and then multiplied by 50.4, since the gross calorific value of natural gas is 50.4 MJ/kg. The resulting values are summed, therefore obtaining the thermal energy from natural gas.  

Note 1: The value of natural gas reported in table 1 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. This is why the amount of natural gas in table 1 was considered instead.

Note 2: The gross calorific values of natural gas (40.3 MJ/m3 and 50.4 MJ/kg) were taken from Table 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3.

Note 3: The amount of titanium slag required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (1.77473 kg) is calculated based on the following facts: i) 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 is required for the production of 1 kg of titanium sponge (consult titanium sponge production dataset) ii) approximately 0.44787 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) is required for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (consult titanium tetrachloride dataset).

exchanges.description:
The amounts of water consumption during the mining and titanium slag production process are 15.84 kg per kg of titanium concentrate and 6.36 kg per kg of titanium slag respectively. These values were taken from table S2 and S4 of the supplemetary materials of Liao et al (2012) publication. The first value was multiplied by 2.2, since approximately 2.2 kg of ilmenite concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of titania slag (94% TiO2) (for more information consult the titanium in ground exchange comment). Assumed density of water: 1000 kg/m3.
Note: The value of water reported in table 1 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. Because of that, the amount reported in the Gao et al (2018) publication was not considered. Furthermore, no water input is reported in the Gao publication for the titanium slag smelting process. As a worst-case scenario, the water from the Liao publication was instead considered here.

Reference: Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4


Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

exchanges.description:
The amount of wastewater is based on water balance and is calculated by subtracting the amount of water emitted to air (15% of water input - consult water emission to air exchange comment) and the amount of water contained in the tailings (30% of the mass of tailings since 70% of the tailings is dry mass - consult non-sulfidic tailings exchange comment) from the amount of water required (0.0412 m3 - consult water unspecified natural origin exchange comment). 

Note: The amount of wastewater reported in table 2 in the column ''ore mining and dressing'' of Gao et al (2018) publication was not taken into account because the inventory in that column has been mass-allocated. This is why the calculation of wastewater based on water balance was preferred instead. 


Reference: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.
